item.description:
Since the first geocaching hike went over so well, here's round two. And as a response to my intense desire to have a cooldown after our hard work bushwhacking around Kettletown, I thought the beach might be a nice place to have our next romp.

Hammonassett State Park

Hammonassett State Park has the longest shoreline beach in Connecticut and attracts over 1 million visitors each season. And in addition to the beach are hiking and biking trails, and of course, geocaches.

Geocaches at Hammonassett State Park

For those of you new to the sport, geocaching is one of the best ways that I have found to find new and exciting places to visit, especially when you are unfamiliar with a place. Below is a link to some of the commonly asked questions about what geocaching is and how the sport works.

Geocaching FAQ

In the files section you will find a map of the park. We will meet at the parking area at the far FAR end of the park near the point marked "Meigs Point Nature Center." (On the map it's the parking area in the bottom right corner.

The plan is to do a couple of geocaches, possibly have lunch at the fabulous Lenny and Joe's just up Route 1 (where there is also a micro-cache that I have yet to find) and then spend some time relaxing on the beach. So, bring your hiking boots, an appetite and your swimming suit for a relaxing Sunday.

item.name: Geocaching Hike and Beach Romp to Hammonassett SP
